page.title: 04HISTORY - ETTRICK VALLEY.
page.content: East of the farm of Wardlaw is Hopehouse, a shepherd's cottage on Tushielaw, a row of three cottages known locally as Needle Street - a tailor had one of them and now a caravan site is in the field that used to be Davie Moffat's cowgang and Flockfield, once a small holding, is now a pottery. Built on the Tushie Law are the ruins of Adam Scott's Tower. He was a notorious border reiver who was according to legend, hanged on his own gallow's tree. The remnants of the original Ettrick Forest are the gnarled trees which grow east of the tower and on the Cacra Bank in Rankleburn. Despite a lot of afforestation in many parts, the chief industry in this little part of 'God's Vineyard' is sheep farming.
